POWER TO CHANGE


What is Pornography addiction?
Pornography addiction, then, is a condition in which a person becomes so dependent on pornography materials (either by reading or viewing it) for their physical and emotional satisfaction that they no longer feel able to stop, even though they know or have seen its negative consequences.

What are the Symptoms of Pornography Addiction?

One of the indicators of porn addiction is a substantial increase in the time spent on the consumption of pornography. While greater frequency is one of the things you should consider, this may not necessarily be the only indication.
For example when you spend hours and hours watching pornography and you didn't realize it.
If you initially started viewing free sites, for example, but now want greater variety or more videos and photos of a particular category, then you may end up spending a surprising amount of money on a number of sites and services.
Engaging in impulsive or risky behaviors just to get your porn fix is another indication of addiction. There are times when you may not have access to your own computer, especially if you are at work or at someone else's house. If your urge to access porn from wherever you are is so great, you just might end up doing it anyway even if you risk getting caught by your boss or your friend.
Finally, when you tried to stop consuming porn and experienced unexplained physical or psychological symptoms (e.g., anxiety, anger or irritability, depression, or some physical signs of stress) which disappear when you go back to viewing porn, then it's a very clear sign that you have already been addicted to pornography.

How Did You Start Getting Addicted?

Addiction to pornography can be likened to a host of other addictions and can be caused by pretty much the same things. If you are unhappy or feel a certain lack in some areas of your life, you may be more susceptible to becoming addicted, since the substance or activity of choice acts as filler to something that you felt was missing in your life.

You are Hurting Yourself

 Many men don't realize that their porn addiction hurts them as well as their wife or girlfriend. Your girl knows about your porn addiction, whether you think so or not. This makes her feel inadequate in the bedroom, which leads to a lack of self-esteem and self-confidence. When a woman is suffering from low self-esteem, her performance in the bedroom also suffers. To put it bluntly, she's just not all that into it. That makes your sex life boring, which adds to the problem.

The Importance of Seeking Help

Be honest with yourself and admit that you have become addicted to pornography if most of the symptoms apply to you. By admitting that you have a problem, you will be taking the first step towards addressing it.
It may be hard for you to stop your addiction by yourself, so seek professional help.
It is important to have a trusted friend or a support system to assist you in your recovery efforts, because you could very quickly spiral back into the same unwanted behavior if you attempt to overcome the addiction alone.
Finally, remember that you have to want to overcome the addiction. You have to recognize its negative effects in your life and sincerely want to change. Knowing your value as a person will go a long way to help you in your goal of achieving a healthy sexual life.

How to Get Your Groove Back?

• Be your own best friend...
• Self-esteem is how we feel or think about ourselves. You inherently know your values and your needs.
• Get help and start to make changes, day-by-day and moment-by-moment that will bring your current reality into alignment with who you are as a person. The first important step in accomplishing this is to gain control over your internal critical self-talk.
• Seek professional help

TESTIMONIALS
1. Addiction ruled my life. I had always thought that I just needed to try a little harder or to be a little better, but after ten years of drowning, I finally admitted that I could not to this by myself, or at least that I didn't have to. When I let go of that last shred of pride I finally started making progress. I agreed to go to an addiction recovery meeting. Here on campus I found others that were facing the same issue having the same struggles. I found strength and gained support that continued to inspire me as I stumbled my way through recovery. I wasn't perfect, but there was real progress, lasting progress. Piece by piece I was getting my confidence back. I took the fight off of its traditional battleground and provided myself a real change. At beating this I had to sacrifice, it was uncomfortable and difficult but with the Savior's help I did it. I cannot imagine being back in those chains and I cannot describe how much peace and confidence this freedom has given me. The Lord has begun to restore my life to me. My dreams have become more realities. I am married now and serve actively in the church. I have the confidence of my spouse and the knowledge that I can stand before my God today or any day. I have seen blessing after blessing and have been able to fully enjoy them without reservation. I have scars and there are still things I choose to give up, things I choose to sacrifice in order to indicate the changes that have taken place in me. But they seem like nothing compared to the power and peace of my recovery. My advice is; don't give up and don't let pride keep you from everything you have every wanted to enjoy in this life. There is still time to overcome all things through the Savior's help. Take advantage of the many blessings, tools, and resources this church and campus have to offer, and you will begin to see real progress, you will begin to hope again because you the power to change.

TIPS
Think carefully about why you want to avoid online pornography
Make a promise to yourself that you will try not to watch pornography
Look at yourself in the mirror
Get rid of everything on your computer that is even remotely related to pornography.
Don't spend lonely nights surfing the Internet
Try not to be alone in a room with the computer
Before turning on your computer, make a list (on paper) of all the things you want to accomplish
Instead of spending so much time alone on the computer, develop an interest in something else
Try to meditate for a few minutes during the day
Think positive about yourself
Install software to filter pornographic web content (see external links below)
Keep your internet history - do not delete it

SUPPORTING PEOPLE WITH PORNOGRAPHY ADDICTION
• They may not agree that they have a problem.
• They may not want to change what they are doing.
• They may fear consequences (family or friends).
• They may feel embarrassed, and not want to discuss it with you.
• They may feel awkward about discussing personal issues with a professional.
• They may be engaging in this addiction as a way to avoid dealing with another problem that bothers them more.
There is no fast and easy way help someone with an addiction. Overcoming an addiction requires great willpower and determination, so if they do not want to change what they are doing, trying to persuade them to get help is unlikely to work.
However, you can take steps that will help your loved one to make changes over the long term, and will help you to cope with a loved one with an addiction.
